DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Mass Site Glioblastoma Glioblastoma Anatomic Site
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The named locations of a malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade IV) which is preferentially located in the cerebral hemispheres of the brain.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells._The anatomic site of the tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Property.preferredDefinition: The anatomic site of the tumor.

Concepts.definition: The anatomic site of the tumor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: CPTAC: Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 1/2/20 jk Released per CPTAC SME (Linda) for PRAD Baseline CRF.   7/26/19 jk revised OC concept per CPTAC input.  6/26/19 jk created for CPTAC Baseline CRFs.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The most malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade IV).  It is composed of poorly differentiated neoplastic astrocytes and it is characterized by the presence of cellular polymorphism, nuclear atypia, brisk mitotic activity, vascular thrombosis, microvascular proliferation and necrosis. It typically affects adults and is preferentially located in the cerebral hemispheres. It may develop from diffuse astrocytoma WHO grade II or anaplastic astrocytoma (secondary glioblastoma, IDH-mutant), but more frequently, it manifests after a short clinical history de novo, without evidence of a less malignant precursor lesion (primary glioblastoma, IDH- wildtype). (Adapted from WHO)_Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the brain located anterior to the parietal lobes at the front of each cerebral hemisphere.

Concepts.definition: The part of the brain located anterior to the parietal lobes at the front of each cerebral hemisphere.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 5.13.21 Updated definition to match current NCIt. mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the four regions of cortex in each cerebral hemisphere. It is located posterior to the temporal lobe and inferior to the parietal lobe.

Concepts.definition: One of the four regions of cortex in each cerebral hemisphere. It is located posterior to the temporal lobe and inferior to the parietal lobe.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 5.26.21 Updated definition to match current NCIt. mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A directive to indicate a response not listed.

Concepts.definition: A directive to indicate a response not listed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the lobes of the cerebral hemisphere located superiorly to the occipital lobe and posteriorly to the frontal lobe. Cognition and visuospatial processing are its main functions.

Concepts.definition: One of the lobes of the cerebral hemisphere located superiorly to the occipital lobe and posteriorly to the frontal lobe. Cognition and visuospatial processing are its main functions.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 5.26.21 Updated definition to match current NCIt. mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lower lateral part of the cerebral hemisphere.

Concepts.definition: One of the cerebral lobes. It is located inferior to the frontal and parietal lobes and anterior to the occipital lobe.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The most malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade IV).  It is composed of poorly differentiated neoplastic astrocytes and it is characterized by the presence of cellular polymorphism, nuclear atypia, brisk mitotic activity, vascular thrombosis, microvascular proliferation and necrosis. It typically affects adults and is preferentially located in the cerebral hemispheres. It may develop from diffuse astrocytoma WHO grade II or anaplastic astrocytoma (secondary glioblastoma, IDH-mutant), but more frequently, it manifests after a short clinical history de novo, without evidence of a less malignant precursor lesion (primary glioblastoma, IDH- wildtype). (Adapted from WHO):Named locations of or within the body.

Concepts.definition: The most malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade 4).  It is composed of poorly differentiated neoplastic astrocytes and is characterized by the presence of cellular polymorphism, nuclear atypia, brisk mitotic activity, vascular thrombosis, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. It typically affects adults and is preferentially located in the cerebral hemispheres. (Adapted from WHO)
Named locations of or within the body.
